title: ISSS608-Lesson Learning Site
text:
Welcome to ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Applications.
Website owner: Chang Fang Yu
In this website, you will find her learning journey in ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Applications.



The picture sources from zh.pngtree.com

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
The code chunk below use p_load() of Pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("Data/Exam_data.csv")

Rows: 322 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE
dbl (3): ENGLISH, MATHS, SCIENCE

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.






ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE)) +
  geom_bar()













R Graphicsggplot2



hist(exam_data$MATHS)











ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black", 
                 fill="grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")














ggplot(data=exam_data)












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS))















ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)

Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with
`binwidth`.










ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)  












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram()   

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.













ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20,            
                 color="black",      
                 fill="light blue")  












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="grey30")












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_density()     









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS,       
           x= GENDER)) +    
  geom_boxplot()  









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point()   












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)  















ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour ="red",        
               size=4)    












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             fun="mean",           
             colour="red",          
             size=4)  












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(size=0.5)

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'










ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
















ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_wrap(~ CLASS)












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_grid(~ CLASS)















ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()












ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, size=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'










ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
















ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()









ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
The code chunk below use p_load() of Pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("Data/Exam_data.csv")

Rows: 322 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE
dbl (3): ENGLISH, MATHS, SCIENCE

ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

       aes(x = RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: About
text: I’m Fang Yu(Iris). This is my personal website to publish my learning journey in ISSS608 Visaul Analytics and Applications.

title: Hands-on Exercise 00 : working with tidyverse
text:
Getting Started
Loading tidyverse onto r environment by using the code chunk below.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)



Importing data

realis2019 <- read_csv("data/REALIS2019.csv")


popdata_fat <- read_csv("data/PopData2019_fat.csv")



Pivoting data

popdata_long <- popdata_fat %>%
  pivot_longer(c(3:21),
               names_to = "Age Group",
               values_to = "Population")



Export and Import R data files(.rds)

#|eval: FALSE
write_rds(popdata_long, "data/popData_long.rds")


#|echo: FALSE
popdata_long <- read_rds("data/popdata_long.rds")



Select and filter columns

realis2019_filtered <- realis2019 %>%
select(`Project Name`, `Type of Sale`, `Transacted Price ($)`, `Property Type`, `Unit Price ($ psm)`) %>%
  filter(`Property Type` == "Condominium"| 
           `Property Type` == "Apartment") %>%
  filter(`Type of Sale` == "New Sale") %>%
  filter(`Unit Price ($ psm)` <= 11000)

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse) 





exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse) 





exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
Beyond ggplot2 Annotation: ggrepel

Working with ggrepel

The plotThe code














ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(color = "darkslategray3") +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID), 
                   fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
Beyond ggplot2 Themes

The plotThe code














ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  theme_bw() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") 





Working with ggtheme package

The plotThe code














ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_economist()






Working with hrbtheme package

The plotThe code














ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="deepskyblue3", 
                 fill="darkslategray3") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum()





The plotThe code














ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="cyan4", 
                 fill="azure1") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum(axis_title_size = 18,
              base_size = 15,
              grid = "Y")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
Beyond Single Graph

The plotThe code














p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="deepskyblue3", 
                 fill="darkslategray3") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")





The plotThe code














p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="deepskyblue3", 
                 fill="darkslategray3") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")





The plotThe code














p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(color = "darkslategray3") +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores vs. Maths scores for Primary 3")





Combining two ggplot2 graphs

The plotThe code














p1 + p2






Combining three ggplot2 graphs

The plotThe code














(p1 / p2) | p3






Creating a composite figure with tag

The plotThe code














(p1 / p2) | p3






Creating figure with insert

The plotThe code














p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)






Creating a composite figure by using patchwork and ggtheme

The plotThe code














patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_pander() & theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=8, margin = margin(t=5)),#above
                          axis.title.y = element_text(size=8, margin = margin(r=5)),
                          axis.text.x = element_text(size = 8),  
                          axis.text.y = element_text(size = 6),
                          plot.title = element_text(size = 10))

title: Hands-on Exercise 3
text:
pacman::p_load(ggiraph, plotly, 
               patchwork, DT, tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3
text:
pacman::p_load(ggiraph, plotly, 
               patchwork, DT, tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 3
text:
Importing Data

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 3
text:
Interactive Data Visualisation - ggiraph methods

Tooltip effect with tooltip aesthetic

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(
    aes(tooltip = ID),
    stackgroups = TRUE, 
    binwidth = 1, 
    method = "histodot") +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, 
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(
  ggobj = p,
  width_svg = 6,
  height_svg = 6*0.618
)
